title: In-N-Out owner Lynsi Snyder reveals the role her faith plays in the success of the hipster favorite
text:
Secretive billionaire In-N-Out heiress Lynsi Snyder has lifted the lid on the role her Evangelical Faith plays in the burger empire, saying it helped her heal from three failed marriages in her 20s, and helped her deal with the death of her father to a drug overdose.

Snyder, who was named the youngest female on the Forbes 400 Richest Americans list in 2018, has a reported net worth of $3billion, thanks to the booming West Coast burger chain.

The 37-year-old, who inherited the business from her grandparents, has spoken publicly about her life only a handful of times over the past decade.

But in a rare interview with the Christian Post, the mother-of-four revealed she faced a brief addiction to alcohol and drugs to cope with the fallout from divorcing three times in her 20s, and her father's death from a drug overdose in 1999 before turning to her faith.

In-N-Out heiress Lynsi Snyder is notoriously private and rarely talks about her surprisingly tumultuous road to success

Snyder's achievements speak for themselves; she was named the youngest female on the Forbes 400 Richest Americans list last year and has a reported net worth of $3billion thanks to her booming West Coast burger chain

'I finally found that the deep need in my heart can only be filled by Jesus and my identity in Him,' she said.

The since born-again Christian first married her high school sweetheart, Jeremiah Seawell, in 2000 before the couple divorced three years later. She then tied the knot to Richard Martinez, whom she has two children with, in 2004, but their matrimony ended in 2011.

By 2004, Snyder said her wild streak was in full effect and she developed an addiction to alcohol and marijuana.

She married her third husband, Val Torres Jr., who she has one child with, in 2011 before they divorced in 2014.

Snyder married her high school sweetheart, Jeremiah Seawell, in 2000 before the couple divorced three years later

She tied the knot to Richard Martinez (left) in 2004, but they divorced in 2011. Her third husband, Val Torres Jr., is pictured right

Third time wasn't a charm for Snyder - she says she then discovered Torres had been cheating on her for nearly four years and claims he was only interested in her for financial benefits.

'I was calling out to God as my third marriage was failing. I was in a place where I felt I couldn't do ministry because my own heart and home were a mess,' she told the Christian Post.

'My husband and I were in constant turmoil. I became desperate for the hope that I could be used by God despite my circumstances.'

'I was calling out to God as my third marriage was failing. I was in a place where I felt I couldn't do ministry because my own heart and home were a mess,' Snyder said

In-N-Out heiress Lynsi Snyder was last year named the youngest female on the Forbes 400 Richest Americans list, but life wasn't always so simple for her

She said she has learned from her experiences that before the 'journey of marriage' it is important to spend time 'healing with Jesus'.

In the aftermath of her failed third marriage, she founded nonprofit organization Army of Love.

One day, she was driving through New Orleans when she heard Isaiah 61, in particular the passage which reads: 'He has sent me to bind up the brokenhearted, to proclaim freedom for the captives and release from darkness for the prisoners.'

While waiting for approval of a nonprofit tax-exemption for her organization, she met her fourth and current spouse, Sean Ellingson, who she has her two youngest children with. Ellingson is a former In-N-Out employee.

'I find it amazing that my quest for love was fulfilled in my time alone with Jesus so that I was ready for my husband and my calling,' she said.

In-N-Out was founded by her grandparents Harry and Esther Snyder in 1948. It was passed onto her father before Snyder became the 6th President of In-N-Out in 2010, succeeding her brother-in-law, Mark Taylor.

Snyder said her grandparents had set the bar high for her and she can only try to raise it.

The businesses' Christian roots are evident in the bible verse taken from John 3:16, printed on the sides of the soda cups.

The verse reads: 'For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life.'

The businesses' Christian roots are evident in the bible verse taken from John 3:16, printed on the sides of the soda cups. The verse reads: 'For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life'

Two more verses have been added in recent times, including Proverbs 24:16 which reads: ' ... the wicked shall fall into mischief' and Luke 6:35 which reads: 'But love ye your enemies, and do good.'

Snyder explained it was her uncle Rich's idea to print the bible quotes onto the In-N-Out cups and wrappers in the 1990s, adding that it will always be a family business. Rich died in a plane crash in 1993.

The In-N-Out burger chain is known for its simple menu and for being a hot spot for Hollywood stars. It only exists in six states, mostly on the West Coast.

The company's business practices have been noted for employee-centered policies and is one of the few fast food chains in the United States to pay its employees more than state minimum wage guidelines -starting at $14 per hour in California.

In a 2014 interview with Orange Coast Magazine, Snyder said she has been the target of two attempted kidnappings.

She told CBS News in 2015 that her family back away from the limelight because they don't want 'a bunch of attention'.
description: In-N-Out heiress and devout Evangelical Christian Lynsi Snyder, 37, described in a rare interview how finding God had helped her to fulfill a deep need in her heart.
